stream_context.summary: Kaze live-maps the inside of Course 14’s pyramid sub-area for the papercraft level, brainstorming how to make an eight-red-coin maze that feels confusing at first but quickly "clicks" once the player grasps its structure. He shows off other recent progress (a saw sub-area for Course 15), play-tests difficulty, discovers a new BLJ bug, and chats about monetization, team feedback, and design philosophy.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 is nearly finished; only two sub-areas were missing before this stream, and Kaze is now building the inside-the-pyramid red-coin maze, making Course 14 content-complete.

The maze concept evolved from complex color-coding ideas to a single main path with eight one-way shortcut branches, each holding a red coin; understanding that structure should “resolve the confusion.”
development_findings.quote: I want it confusing at first and then you suddenly understand—one main path with a bunch of small paths along it that connect back to the main path.

development_findings.summary: Kaze wants landmarks—a large central cliff with visible entrances—to let players see many paths at once and orient themselves.
development_findings.quote: You come out and see four or five other entrances below you and go, ‘Oh, that’s where that is.’

development_findings.summary: He rejects heavier puzzle mechanics (passwords, switches, mirrors) because they contradict RTYI’s design of intuitive discovery over explicit logic puzzles.
development_findings.quote: That’s too much puzzle. Even in the puzzle level, the puzzle is realizing there is a puzzle.

development_findings.summary: A new backwards-long-jump bug appeared; Mario can BLJ where he shouldn’t. Kaze flags it as a critical fix and suspects a C-value issue.
development_findings.quote: Apparently you can BLJ—oh my God. That’s a very important bug to fix.

development_findings.summary: A render-mode oversight produced a wireframe ‘reality-destroying’ effect on objects; Kaze identifies it as missing alpha coverage settings.
development_findings.quote: Turns everything into wireframe somehow—the wireframe must be from alpha x opacity and no alpha coverage.

development_findings.summary: Kaze completed a saw-blade platforming sub-area for Course 15 off-stream; Zeina struggled with it, confirming it’s the hardest area so far but acceptable for Course 15 difficulty.
development_findings.quote: When Zeina played, she had trouble beating it, but I think the difficulty is fine considering it’s Course 15.

development_findings.summary: The Course 1 demo is essentially done; he just needs to package it for release.
development_findings.quote: One is fully finished and the demo is ready—I just need to actually, like, make the demo ready.

development_findings.summary: Tentative naming: the pyramid’s overworld area still lacks a final name; ‘Handmade Heights’ and ‘Crafty Canyons’ are in contention.
He reminds viewers that Course 15 will be a war-themed level; his ‘release tomorrow’ comment sounded facetious but indicates nearing completion.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s guiding philosophy: create initial overwhelm followed by an ‘aha’ moment rooted in spatial understanding, not explicit puzzles.
context_findings.quote: I want the confusion from being overwhelmed… and then through being in here, you realize what's going on and can navigate competently.

context_findings.summary: He praises Majora’s Mask for world-building and side-content pacing, contrasting it with Twilight Princess’ dungeon-centric structure.
context_findings.quote: Majora’s Mask formula is perfect… it’s all the world-building in between that I really like.

context_findings.summary: Financial transparency: he shows YouTube revenue (~$900 this month; ~$10k a year) and monthly living costs (~$2,800 for wife and child).
context_findings.quote: Look, my analytics—$900 this month… with a wife and the kid my monthly expenses are $2,800.

context_findings.summary: Momentary frustration and curiosity when discovering the BLJ bug; worry about player difficulty but confidence in design.
He discusses social-media reach and timing posts, considering Twitter monetization but treating it as uncertain bonus income.
context_findings.quote: If Twitter impressions worked like that, that’d be crazy—$600 a month.

biobak.summary: Gave live feedback on Twitter post timing and suggested cardboard-with-paper texture tweaks for the styrofoam parts.
biobak.quote: Posting times are stupid—schedule the post for the next day. Nothing we do is time sensitive.

zeina.summary: Play-tested the Course 15 saw area; her struggle confirmed high difficulty.
zeina.quote: Zeina played and she didn’t really have a shot at beating it, so that’s why I feel like it’s a little difficult.

key_stories.title: Making a Maze that Teaches Itself
key_stories.summary: Kaze begins with several over-complicated ideas for the pyramid maze (color coding, mirrored halves, footprints). Realizing technical and design drawbacks, he pivots to a single looping main path with one-way shortcuts, each hiding a red coin. The design now matches his goal: confusion followed by clarity.
key_stories.challenge: Create an eight-red-coin area that feels like a maze without frustrating players.
key_stories.process: Brainstorms color codes, landmarks, anti-left-wall tactics, evaluates technical limits, finally settles on main-path-with-shortcuts concept.
key_stories.outcome: Level layout sketched during stream; next step is texturing and platforming polish.
key_stories.key_quote: I still want the player to feel they’re free to go anywhere, so I’m adding one-way shortcuts—you can’t just follow the left wall.

key_stories.title: A Surprise BLJ Bug
key_stories.summary: While demonstrating new movement options, Kaze accidentally performs a backwards long jump in an unintended spot. He pauses normal level design to note the issue.
key_stories.challenge: Prevent legacy glitches from re-entering the decomp-based engine.
key_stories.process: Recreates glitch, suspects C-value handling error, flags it for off-stream debugging.
key_stories.outcome: Bug logged as ‘very important’ for future fix; no solution yet.
key_stories.key_quote: Apparently you can BLJ—oh my God. That’s a very important bug to fix.

key_stories.title: Zeina vs. the Saw Blades
key_stories.summary: Kaze finished a saw-themed sub-area for Course 15. Zeina’s play-test showed it was exceptionally hard.
key_stories.challenge: Ensuring late-game difficulty is tough but fair.
key_stories.process: Zeina attempts run, struggles; Kaze observes and weighs adjustments.
key_stories.outcome: He keeps the difficulty but flags potential fine-tuning; validates Course 15 as the hardest zone.
key_stories.key_quote: She didn’t really have a shot at beating it, so that’s why I feel like it’s a little difficult.
